Special consideration will be given to experience in Odoo version migrations and the ability to ensure data traceability and integrity. * Approximate number of records to migrate Companies: 1 Contacts: 150k Products : 20k / Variants: 22k Transfers: 34k Landed Cost 1,4K Quotations / Sales Ordesr:  19k Quotations / Purchase Ordesr 3k Manufacturing Orders: 1k Lots / Serial Numbers: 11k Invoices (Sales and Purchases): 23k *** NOTE ***: If you present your proposal in several milestones, you must consider that funds will not be released until the first two phases have been completed. title: Firebase Push Notification Tracking and Reporting - Upwork
description: Implement Google Analytics 4 in a React Native app and related applications User Story As a Product Manager, I want to integrate Google Analytics 4 into our React Native mobile application, So that I can track and analyze user interactions with push notifications and chat messages (read/unread, engaged with, etc.) across both Android and iOS platforms. Acceptance Criteria Google Analytics 4 Integration: Google Analytics 4 (GA4) must be fully integrated into the React Native mobile application, ensuring compatibility with both Android and iOS versions. Tracking Push Notifications: Track delivery rates, open rates, and click-through rates of push notifications. Segment data based on notification type, user demographics, and engagement metrics. Chat Message Analytics: Track when chat messages are sent, received, read (with timestamp), and when users engage with the chat (e.g., responding to prompts). Analyze chat engagement rates to understand how users interact with the AI chatbot. User Engagement Metrics: Measure and report on user engagement metrics such as session duration, chatbot interaction depth (number of exchanged messages per session), and repeat usage frequency. Identify patterns of usage and engagement to inform future enhancements. Cross-Platform Compatibility: Ensure that analytics tracking works seamlessly across both Android and iOS platforms without affecting app performance or user experience. Data Privacy Compliance: Implement the integration in compliance with data privacy laws and regulations (e.g., GDPR, CCPA). Ensure users are informed about what data is collected and have the option to opt-out of tracking. User Segmentation and Behavioral Analysis: Provide capabilities to segment users based on behavior, preferences, and engagement levels. Use this data to perform detailed analysis and improve user experience. Real-time Analytics Dashboard in Google Analytics 4: Implement a real-time analytics dashboard within Google Analytics 4 that allows for monitoring key metrics related to push notifications and chat interactions. Create a PowerBI report for the metrics. Documentation and Training: Provide detailed documentation on the data points being tracked, and guidance on interpreting the data. Train the product and marketing teams on using GA4 to derive actionable insights. Testing and Validation: Before the full rollout, conduct thorough testing to validate data accuracy and reliability across different devices and operating systems. Ensure there are no discrepancies in reported metrics between Android and iOS platforms. Definition of Done (DoD) Development Completion: All development tasks for integrating GA4 and setting up the required analytics have been completed. Code Review and Quality Assurance: The integration code has been reviewed for quality and performance. Any identified issues have been addressed and resolved. Testing: Integration and analytics tracking have been rigorously tested across different devices and OS versions for both Android and iOS. All tests confirm accurate tracking and data reporting. Performance Benchmarking: The integration does not negatively impact app performance. Load times and responsiveness are within acceptable thresholds. Privacy Compliance Verification: The app complies with relevant data privacy regulations, and user consent mechanisms for analytics tracking are in place and functioning as expected. Documentation and Training Completed: Comprehensive documentation is available, and training sessions for the relevant teams have been conducted successfully. Stakeholder Approval: The product manager and key stakeholders have reviewed and approved the implementation, confirming that all acceptance criteria have been met. Deployment: The updated app with GA4 integration has been successfully deployed to both the App Store and Google Play Store, with no critical issues reported by early users. Feedback Mechanism: A process for collecting and analyzing user feedback on the new analytics features is established, ensuring continuous improvement. Possible additional Scope: 1. Help implement Google Analytics across all of our apps. 2. Help assess if Mix Panel is needed in addition to GA4Skills: Push Notifications, Google Analytics, Firebase, Mobile App Development, Firebase Cloud Firestore, PostgreSQL Programming, AWS Lambda, Snowflake

title: Redis/Tile38 geospatial queries, data structure - consultation needed - Upwork
description: We have a real time stream of points and a stream of polygons (square in shape, overlapping, different size, short lived). We need to design database and its queries that provide in real-time answer to a question: "Within what polygons are points at the time of points or polygons creation?" For this task ideally we need someone with practical experience in real-time data and GIS. On Redis side we need advice on how to partition our data, how to handle it on ingestion/extraction (what pub/sub mechanism to use), whether we need to distribute our data geographically and how, what performance we can expect to get. Person needs to have a good understanding of Redis architecture and common approaches taken their for high load real-time data. On GIS side we need advice on what GIS queries are going to be the fastest, what geospatial index is most suitable and if standard Redis geo index will suit our use case and if not how to transform our data so that we can use it in Redis; how suitable for our purpose is Tile38 and if it is possible to use Tile38's geofences for our stream of polygons and points. Skills: Database Architecture, Database Design, Redis, GIS

**Front-End Development:** Utilizing React for responsive user interfaces. - **AI-Powered Matching Algorithm:** Custom algorithm integrated into Django for precise user-closet pairing. - **Subscription Management:** Managed through Stripe, offering tiered options for rental allowances. - **User Experience:** Prioritizing intuitive design for seamless interaction. - **Legal and Privacy Considerations:** Ensuring compliance with GDPR and CCPA regulations. - **Development and Deployment Tools:** Utilizing Docker for containerization and Kubernetes or Heroku for scalability and hosting. **Additional Considerations:** - Exploring React Native for cross-platform app development. - Continuous assessment of API costs, scalability, and privacy compliance to optimize platform performance. The Project endeavors to set a new standard in fashion rental, delivering a personalized, convenient, and secure experience for women worldwide. With advanced technology and a commitment to user satisfaction, we aim to redefine the way women engage with their closets and each other. To help us evalute your candidacy , please apply with the following questions answered: 1. **Technical Skills:**    - Can you provide examples of projects where you've worked with Django, PostgreSQL, and React?    - How comfortable are you with integrating third-party APIs such as Clarifai, Vogue Runway API, Stripe, and Auth0?    - Have you ever implemented AI algorithms in your projects, particularly for matching purposes?    - What experience do you have with containerization tools like Docker and deployment platforms like Kubernetes or Heroku? 2. **Problem-Solving and Creativity:**    - How would you approach developing a matching algorithm that accurately pairs users with closets based on their body types and style preferences?    - Can you suggest any innovative ideas for enhancing user experience and engagement within the platform?    - How would you handle challenges related to scalability and performance as the platform grows? 3. **Legal and Compliance Awareness:**    - Are you familiar with GDPR and CCPA regulations, especially concerning user data handling and privacy policies?    - How do you ensure that the platforms you develop comply with legal requirements and industry standards? 4. **Project Management and Planning:**    - Can you describe your approach to project planning and management, including timelines, milestones, and resource allocation?    - How do you prioritize tasks and manage deadlines in a fast-paced development environment?Skills: Django, MySQL, React, PHP, Bubble.io, RESTful API, JavaScript, Node.js, React Native, Web Development, PostgreSQL

If you meet all the criteria listed above, please respond to this online survey job posting only if you consent to participating in this survey and allowing us to use certain details from your public Upwork profile for statistical purposes. title: Perl script ca.2010 (5.10.1) (OR 5.30.0) modification to solve character encoding problems - Upwork
description: EXISTING Perl script to be Modified: Old (5.10.1) Perl script reads filenames in a directory on a linux filesystem and uses DBI to read an Oracle database to find those files names  and *future* (file location) paths in the database. Script uses the  path data in the database to [find or create] those path locations in the filesystem. Script then moves the existing files to those path locations. This script has worked perfectly for 12-14 years WHEN THE PATHNAMES and FILENAMES were all composed of lower/plain ASCII characters. Now PATHNAMES and FILENAMES need to allow upper ASCII characters such as ä, Ø, etc. [Scandinavian and common European characters]. The OLD Perl script was from well before the time that Perl was built to do character encoding well.  I am not sure, but I *think* Perl is INTERNALLY using some ISO-8859 encoding (or something else???) instead of UTF-8.  The input data (filenames and paths) from Oracle is UTF-8. The existing files in the  linux filesystem are UTF-8 names.  The output needs to be UTF-8 to [find create] the target directory names (paths) and then move the exiting files into those directories. We are NOT currently able to upgrade the Perl version.  We have to either use (with the same script) either 5.10.1 or 5.30.0.on the systems we have.  [This aspect cannot be changed at this time; we are planning on a long-term total replacement in the next two years.] Instead, we either have to... 1) Add an ENCODE Perl module (and how to use it?) to the existing Perl installation(s) (Perl 5.10.01 on Ubuntu Linux 10.04.4) OR (Perl 5.30.0 on Ubuntu Linux 20.04). [Both access the same Oracle 8.x database.  Both the Oracle database and the Linux use UTF-8 encoding. OR 2) Modify the process that the script does and INSTEAD of the script CURRENTLY directly adding paths and files to the filesystem, change the script to instead write out a script-text-file containing "install" command lines. [I have an "install" command example that does work, which we use for something else.] Then I can use an "iconv" command to convert that script-text-file from ISO-8859 (???) to UTF-8. This project is best done by somebody familiar with older Perl versions *and* character encoding problems. Though the Perl script is communicating with an old Oracle database, that part is working okay and does not need any changing.  I do *NOT* think that this project requires any Perl:DBI, Oracle, or PL/SQL skills as long as no changes are made to that part of the script. This could be hourly work or a a fixed price job. In the job definition I selected hourly because of the potential unknowns of the work with old systems.Skills: Perl, Scripting, Linux System Administration

description: **Project Description:** We are seeking an experienced freelance developer to collaborate on an exciting project - PassNumber. This innovative application aims to revolutionize user authentication by replacing traditional passwords with a more secure, image-based method. **Overview of PassNumber:** PassNumber is a cutting-edge app designed to enhance security and user experience in digital authentication. It replaces traditional passwords with a smart, easy, and highly secure method based on a table of icons. **Key Features:** 1. **User Registration**: Users create an account by entering a username and selecting their preferred icons from a table. 2. **Icon Shuffle at Login**: During the login process, these icons are randomly shuffled. Users authenticate by entering their username and the locations of their selected icons. 3. **Enhanced Security**: The app is immune to keyloggers, phishing, and other common cyber attacks. It does not store explicit or hashed passwords, rendering brute force and rainbow table attacks ineffective. 4. **Privacy and Data Security**: In the event of a database breach, the stored data is unusable on other websites, providing an additional layer of security. **Advantages Over Traditional Passwords:** - User-friendly and easier to remember. - Resistant to various hacking methods including brute force, keylogging, phishing, and shoulder surfing. - Easily integrable with various systems. - Highly relevant in the current landscape of increasing cyber attacks. **Applications:** PassNumber is versatile and can be integrated with: - Various website platforms (PHP, ASP .NET, Java). - Operating systems (Windows, MAC, Linux). - Enterprise Management Systems (EMS) like Alfresco and SharePoint. - Customer Relationship Management (CRM) platforms such as Oracle, Salesforce, and Zendesk. **Project Goals:** - Develop a fully functional PassNumber application. - Ensure compatibility with multiple platforms and systems. - Prioritize user experience and security in design and functionality. **Why This Project is Promising:** - It's an open-source GPL3 licensed project (GitHub link). - Targets a global audience across various industries. - Addresses a crucial need in personal and business information security. **What We Are Looking For:** An experienced developer with: - Expertise in application security and user authentication methods. - Proficiency in cross-platform development. - Ability to work collaboratively, incorporating feedback and aligning with the project vision. **Project Timeline and Budget:** 1-3 Months, up to 500$ (negotiable). title: Oracle Micros POS 3700 Integration Specialist - Upwork
description: We're looking for someone with experience in doing integrations for the Oracle Micros RES 3700 POS. We require people with expertise and experience in one or both of the following: (1) Direct integration on the Micros 3700 POS Station itself. We have a USB hardware device that enumerates as a COM port that we would like integrated into the bill/check payment process on the 3700 POS. This would mean adding a tender type to the customer's available payment options guests have, and when this tender is selected the amount of the check/bill is transmitted to the USB device using our SDK with an API we will provide in C#. Then the USB device will respond indicating if the payment was successful or not, at which point the check/bill is cleared/closed. (2) An API integration that would allow our POS's sales transactions, stored in our cloud back office system, to be sent to a customer's RES 3700 database so that sales of items done in our POS can be reflected in the RES 3700 system. We're hoping that this work can be done in about a month's timeframe. If the integration is successful there's a big potential for future work since we can get more customers that are using 3700 Micros POS systems.  Also, the goal is to eventually integrate with Simphony the newer POS offered by Oracle, so future work would follow with a Simphony integration. Skills: Software Integration, Extension & Module Development, .NET Framework, SQL, API Integration, Database

title: Participate in an Academic Survey to Reflect on your Freelancing Experience – DR115 - Upwork
description: Hello, you are being requested to take part in a survey of 25 - 30 minutes for academic research purposes. We will use your answers to guide new and experienced freelancers on building their profiles on labor platforms like Upwork and managing their freelancing career, as well as suggest improvements to the platforms and to policymakers. If you are interested, we can provide you with a brief summary of our major findings from our completed research study once our research is complete (tentatively August 2025 or earlier), after contacting you via Upwork. We welcome freelancers across experience levels, earnings, and ratings who: (i) provide freelancing services on their own (not as part of an agency or company), (ii) are over 18 years of age, (iii) have provided freelancing services for more than 1 year on Upwork, (iv) have worked on freelancing projects in the past 1 year on Upwork (consider July 2022-June 2023 as the past 1 year), and (iv) have a Job Success Score on their profile. If you meet all the criteria listed above, please respond to this online survey job posting only if you consent to participating in this survey and allowing us to use certain details from your public Upwork profile for statistical purposes. Procedure: In this survey you will not have any more risks than you have in normal life. This study has been approved by the researchers' institutional research ethics board. You will not be personally identified in our analysis or reporting. While storing the data from the survey, a participant ID number will be used instead of your name. However, we will collect some information from your public Upwork profile with your consent (e.g., ratings, job category, total earnings, number of jobs, number of successfully completed jobs and jobs in progress, hourly rate, pricing strategy (fixed vs. hourly), profile title and keywords, number of reviews, type of recognition badge, number of years of educational and work experience, number of skill tags, country, gender, job success score, availability of  portfolio, testimonials, certifications, availability badge, and profile video) to understand the difference in freelance experience. Profile information that is captured from your public profile on Upwork with your consent, will be depersonalized for data analysis and reporting so that it is not identifiable with your details and will only be recorded against your participant ID number. These details and your responses will be kept confidential and used for academic purposes only. This study has been approved by the researchers' institutional research ethics board. Data will be stored in a secure academic database on university-licensed cloud storage to ensure confidentiality. Please use a laptop or tablet to complete the survey. We recommend not using mobile. Compensation: You will receive $8 for your participation. Kindly note, you will be compensated upon completion of the entire interview as per standard Upwork processes. At the end of the survey, you will be provided with a random ID number (numerical code) that will need to be shared with us on Upwork Message. This will enable us to process your compensation via the Upwork platform, as per standard Upwork processes. You can stop participating in the survey at any time. You may skip the questions, where applicable or use the ‘Not applicable or NA’/‘Not sure’/‘Prefer not to disclose’ options, or even close the browser to end the survey. While we hope that you will complete the survey, we will compensate you for the first milestone for partial completion of the survey. Your Upwork profile will not be adversely impacted in any way with your participation in the survey, even if you choose to terminate the survey midway as we will provide a 5-star rating without feedback upon completion to preserve the research integrity. Survey time: Approximately 25-30 minutes. The actual time may vary. Location: The survey will be conducted virtually, via an online survey platform and will begin only after you provide your consent. Frequency: One-time Consent: We will seek your consent electronically at the start of the online survey regarding: • Consent to participate • Consent to record non-personal information from your public profile without personally identifying you in the data. Please respond to the online survey job posting once you agree with ALL the above requirements. description: I have an ASP.Net Forms (4.5) (VB) web application that displays a small catalog of items (41 items) in a gridview. title: Expert wanted on .NET runtime dependency resolution - Upwork
description: I am creating a universal .NET assembly loader, which works pretty much like Visual Studio and .NET runtime, which automatically loads all dependencies of the assembly and all dependencies of each dependency, and so on, recursively. I run into a problem in creating this loader. YOU HAVE TO READ THE WHOLE TASK AND KNOW THE ANSWER BEFORE YOU PROPOSE. YOU WILL BE IMMEDIATELY BLACKLISTED IF YOU PROPOSE WITHYOUT READHING IT. I am writing a .NET 6.0 console app that uses reflection to - Load an arbitrary class library (DLL) - I can't predict what DLL the end user may load - the possibilities are infinite. - Find out its public types and the methods of each type. - Invoke its methods. For the loaded assembly to work, my app needs to load the whole dependency graph - all of its dependencies and the dependencies of each dependency and so on recursively. For each of the dependency which is itself a DLL, if it is not in the global NuGet packages folder, my app downloads it from NuGet online library and unzips it into the global folder. Is this the right approach? Or is there a fundamentally better approach? A problem I encountered is how to pick the right DLL in the NuGet package folder. In my testing, the target DLL which my console app tried to load and invoke uses Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer 7.0.16 to talk to a SQL Server database. It has a dependency Microsoft.Data.SqlClient 5.1.4. Inside the NuGet package folder of Microsoft.Data.SqlClient 5.1.4, there are the following subfolders that each contains a Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.dll: lib\net6.0 lib\net462 lib\netstandard2.0 lib\netstandard2.1 runtimes\win\lib\net6.0 runtimes\win\lib\net462 runtimes\win\lib\netstandard2.0 runtimes\win\lib\netstandard2.1 You would think that the one in "lib\net6.0" has to be the right one, because my console app targets .NET 6.0, wouldn't you? But if my console app loads this one, it would case a exception saying this DLL is not supported. However, if I use the one in "runtimes\win\lib\netstandard2.0", everything works. So the question is: where is the knowledge that I should use the Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.dll in folder "runtimes\win\lib\netstandard2.0" instead of "lib\net6.0" for Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer 7.0.16? The following is how to get dependencies of a given DLL. It doesn't contain the knowledge I am after:         NuspecReader nuspecReader = await packageReader.GetNuspecReaderAsync(cancellationToken);         foreach (var dependencyGroup in nuspecReader.GetDependencyGroups())         [                 foreach (NuGet.Packaging.Core.PackageDependency packageDependency in dependencyGroup.Packages)                 [                     ...                 ]         ] However, Visual Studio secretly knows where to get this knowledge, because if I add a reference to Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer 7.0.16 in any .Net 6.0 project, Visual Studio will automatically pick the right Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.dll in the global NuGet packages folder. But where is this knowledge, so my console app can use to load the right DLL? So, if you know the answer, then you can implement the following method, which acquires the knowledge which I don't know where to acquire, then use it to get the right version of DLL to use. public static List[string] GetDependencyFiles(string packageID, string packageVersion) [     // your implemetation ] When I call this function like this: var dependencyFiles = GetDependencyFiles("Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer", "7.0.16"); One of the returned strings should be "C:\Users\frank\.nuget\packages\microsoft.data.sqlclient\5.1.4\runtimes\win\lib\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.Data.SqlClient.dll".Skills: C#, .NET Framework, .NET Core

My thoughts of solution, but you can come with your thoughts too: - Figure out the API calls and;     - Create a Python app that automatically loops through, lookups up and saves the values from the table into a CSV file or SQLite database.     - Create an app in another programming language you choose, that can run on Windows, and that can automatically loop through, look up and save the values from the table into a CSV or SQLite database. - Create some sort of patch that add this functionality to the original program. title: Participate in an Academic Survey to Reflect on your Freelancing Experience – DR139 - Upwork
description: Hello, you are being requested to take part in a survey of 25 - 30 minutes for academic research purposes. Once you begin the survey, you have up to 72 hours to complete it, beyond which time the survey platform will mark your responses as incomplete. We will use your answers to guide new and experienced freelancers on building their profiles on labor platforms like Upwork and managing their freelancing career, as well as suggest improvements to the platforms and to policymakers. If you are interested, we can provide you with a brief summary of our major findings from our completed research study once our research is complete (tentatively August 2025 or earlier), after contacting you via Upwork. We welcome freelancers across experience levels, earnings, and ratings who: (i) provide freelancing services on their own (not as part of an agency or company), (ii) are over 18 years of age, (iii) have provided freelancing services for more than 1 year on Upwork, (iv) have worked on freelancing projects in the past 1 year on Upwork (consider July 2022-June 2023 as the past 1 year), and (iv) have a Job Success Score on their profile. If you meet all the criteria listed above, please respond to this online survey job posting only if you consent to participating in this survey and allowing us to use certain details from your public Upwork profile for statistical purposes. Procedure: In this survey you will not have any more risks than you have in normal life. This study has been approved by the researchers' institutional research ethics board. You will not be personally identified in our analysis or reporting. While storing the data from the survey, a participant ID number will be used instead of your name. However, we will collect some information from your public Upwork profile with your consent (e.g., ratings, job category, total earnings, number of jobs, number of successfully completed jobs and jobs in progress, hourly rate, pricing strategy (fixed vs. hourly), profile title and keywords, number of reviews, type of recognition badge, number of years of educational and work experience, number of skill tags, country, gender, job success score, availability of  portfolio, testimonials, certifications, availability badge, and profile video) to understand the difference in freelance experience. Profile information that is captured from your public profile on Upwork with your consent, will be depersonalized for data analysis and reporting so that it is not identifiable with your details and will only be recorded against your participant ID number. These details and your responses will be kept confidential and used for academic purposes only. This study has been approved by the researchers' institutional research ethics board. Data will be stored in a secure academic database on university-licensed cloud storage to ensure confidentiality. Please use a laptop or tablet to complete the survey. We recommend not using mobile. Compensation: You will receive $8 for your participation. Kindly note, you will be compensated upon completion of the entire interview as per standard Upwork processes. At the end of the survey, you will be provided with a random ID number (numerical code) that will need to be shared with us on Upwork Message. This will enable us to process your compensation via the Upwork platform, as per standard Upwork processes. You can stop participating in the survey at any time. You may skip the questions, where applicable or use the ‘Not applicable or NA’/‘Not sure’/‘Prefer not to disclose’ options, or even close the browser to end the survey. While we hope that you will complete the survey, we will compensate you for the first milestone for partial completion of the survey. Your Upwork profile will not be adversely impacted in any way with your participation in the survey, even if you choose to terminate the survey midway as we will provide a 5-star rating without feedback upon completion to preserve the research integrity. Survey time: Approximately 25-30 minutes. The actual time may vary. Location: The survey will be conducted virtually, via an online survey platform and will begin only after you provide your consent. Frequency: One-time Consent: We will seek your consent electronically at the start of the online survey regarding: • Consent to participate • Consent to record non-personal information from your public profile without personally identifying you in the data. Please respond to the online survey job posting once you agree with ALL the above requirements. If you have any more questions, you can contact the primary researchers through Upwork Message.Skills: SQLite, Realm Database, MongoDB, MySQL, Apache Cassandra, API, Database, Database Architecture, Software Architecture & Design, Data Access Layer, RESTful API, PHP Script, Python Script, SOAP API, Business Logic Layer, Database Maintenance, Ruby, C++, ASP, Django, SaaS, PyTorch, TensorFlow, Atlassian Bamboo, AWS Amplify, Azure DevOps

description: Responsibilities. Experience with Performance Tuning and Optimization (PTO), using native monitoring and troubleshooting tools. Assist developers with query tuning and schema refinement. Advanced knowledge of High Availability (HA) and Disaster Recovery (DR) options for MS SQL Server Database administration including software installation, sizing, performance analysis and tuning, query troubleshooting, backup, and recovery. Maintenance of, and response to, monitoring for key processes/systems. Monitor database performance, implement changes, and apply new patches and versions when required. Ability to troubleshoot and problem solve independently and collaboratively. Finding and debugging malfunctioning programs affecting the database integrity. Support and maintain the database utilizing MSSQL, SSRS and SSMS. Backups - Check backups to validate that they were successfully created per your process. Nightly Processing - Review the nightly or early morning processes. SQL Server Error Log - Review the SQL Server error log for any errors or security issues (successful or failed logins) that are unexpected. Windows Event Log - Review the Application Event Log at a minimum to find out if any Windows or hardware related errors or warnings are being written. SQL Server Agent Jobs - Review for failed SQL Server Agent Jobs Performance Logs - Review the performance metrics to determine if your baseline was exceeded or if you had slow points during the day that need to be reviewed Security Logs - Review the security logs from the SQL Server Error Logs to determine if you had a breach or a violation in one of your policies. Storage - Validate you have sufficient storage on your drives to support your databases, backups, batch processes, etc. in the short term. Fragmentation - Review the fragmentation for your databases to determine if you particular indexes must be rebuilt based on analysis from a backup SQL Server Security - Remove unneeded logins and users for individuals that have left the organization, had a change in position, etc. Shrink databases - If databases or transaction logs are larger, than necessary shrink those files to free up disk space. Examine SQL Server wait statistics to see if new ‘pain points’ have become large points of contention within SQL Server. Audit job execution time for dramatic variances against baseline runtimes. Investigate databases for objects that violate established rules. Perform a full index analysis for all databases. Determine unused indexes and disable if appropriate. Determine missing indexes and investigate process to update or add indexes to better cover data usage. Review systems for tuning opportunities. Common tuning indicators include buffer cache hit ratio, page life expectancy, I/O and network performance, long running queries, average CPU utilization, etc. Perform tuning as necessary. title: Migrate Over 1 Million Business Records from SQLite to PostgreSQL for Enhanced Data Management - Upwork
description: # Pre-requisites Access to the source SQLite database and target PostgreSQL database with necessary permissions. Familiarity with SQL, SQLite, and PostgreSQL databases. Tools for data migration (e.g., pgLoader) and backup. Understanding of the data structure and any specific data integrity constraints. #Task Steps 1. Assess and Plan the Migration Perform a thorough assessment of the existing SQLite database schema, relationships, and data types. Identify any SQLite-specific features or data types that may require special handling or conversion for PostgreSQL. Plan the migration process, including timing, necessary downtime, backup strategies, and testing phases. 2. Prepare the PostgreSQL Environment Install and configure the PostgreSQL server, ensuring it is optimized for the expected data volume and access patterns. Create the necessary databases, schemas, and roles with appropriate permissions in PostgreSQL. Review and apply security settings, including access controls and encryption as needed. 3. Data Type Mapping and Schema Conversion Map SQLite data types to their PostgreSQL equivalents, taking care to handle any incompatible types or those that might affect performance differently in PostgreSQL. Convert the SQLite schema to a PostgreSQL-compatible schema, including tables, indexes, views, and triggers. Utilize tools or scripts to automate this process where possible. 4. Data Migration Use a migration tool like pgLoader, which can directly transfer data from SQLite to PostgreSQL, handling schema and data type conversion automatically. In cases requiring manual intervention or custom scripting, ensure scripts are thoroughly tested on a subset of data before full-scale migration. Implement data validation checks during the migration to ensure data integrity and consistency. 5. Testing and Validation Perform comprehensive testing on the PostgreSQL database to verify data integrity, including checks for missing data, data corruption, or any discrepancies. Test the performance of the new database with realistic workloads and queries to ensure it meets or exceeds the performance of the old system. Involve end-users or stakeholders in testing applications or reports that rely on the database to confirm that functionality remains unchanged or improved after the migration. 6. Finalize the Migration Plan for a final synchronization of any data changes that occurred in the SQLite database during the migration process. Once confirmed, switch over applications and users to the new PostgreSQL database. Monitor the system closely for any issues related to performance, security, or data integrity in the days following the migration. 7. Post-Migration Cleanup and Documentation Decommission the old SQLite database after ensuring all data and functionality have been successfully migrated and backed up. Update any documentation to reflect the new database architecture, data flow, and any changes in access or security protocols. Provide training or resources to the team on PostgreSQL features or administration as needed. # Conclusion Migrating over 1 million records from SQLite to PostgreSQL is a complex task requiring careful planning, execution, and testing. This task will significantly improve the company's data handling capabilities in terms of scalability, reliability, and performance, supporting its ongoing and future business operations.Skills: SQLite, PostgreSQL, SQL, MySQL, Database

title: Integration and Automation of Data Retrieval and Storage with Apache NiFi - Upwork
description: **Objective:** Develop a robust workflow that efficiently retrieves, processes, and stores structured data in a target database using Apache NiFi (Version 1.23.2) and MariaDB (Version 10.5.10). The system should ensure reliable error handling for each processing step and will be implemented in a remotely accessible test and development environment. **Tasks:** 1. **Data Retrieval:**    - Retrieve structured data through a defined WebService.    - Implement error handling that responds to retrieval issues such as server failures or network interruptions. 2. **Data Storage:**    - Save the retrieved data as a file in a predefined input folder (INBOX).    - Error handling for file access problems or lack of storage space. 3. **Journaling Data Retrieval:**    - Insert a journal entry for the start of data processing in a journal table.    - Error handling for database connection errors or write errors into the table. 4. **Data Conversion:**    - Convert and prepare the retrieved data for storage in the target fact table.    - Error handling for conversion errors or data format issues. 5. **Data Enrichment:**    - Use an existing database function to supplement the prepared data.    - Error handling for execution errors of the function or data inconsistencies. 6. **Data Injection:**    - Write the prepared data into the target fact table.    - Error handling for write errors or database constraints. 7. **Journal Update:**    - Update the journal entry upon completion of data processing.    - Error handling for issues updating the journal entry. 8. **Archiving:**    - Move the data file to an archive folder (ARCHIVE) after successful processing.    - Error handling for access errors or lack of space in the archive folder. **Requirements:** - Each step must include specific error handling to ensure the system is robust against failures and takes appropriate corrective actions. - The development and testing of the system will take place in a remotely accessible environment to enable flexible and efficient work processes. **Technical Specifications:** - Software used: Apache NiFi 1.23.2, MariaDB 10.5.10. - The implementation must follow best practices for security and data management. **Deliverables:** - Fully implemented and tested processing in Apache NiFi. - Documentation of the system architecture, data flow, and error handling strategies. - Guide for the installation and configuration of the solution in the production environment.Skills: Apache NiFi, MariaDB

title: Need backend developer to modify/add functionality to our existing database - Upwork
description: We have a PHP Laravel api portal and use a MariaDB database. We need our database to be modified and new interfaces/api’s created so we no longer need excel files. I’ll explain the excel files below. Currently we use two excel files to gather content about schools and clients. I will share those files with entities we’d like proposals from after NDAs are signed. We’ll also give access to our source code and portal.   We use the two excel files to conduct analyses and assess what we need to accomplish in order to reach various goals. These are very basic analyses. We are not a financial services or healthcare organization with millions of dynamic data points and circular, complex equations. We have worked with 1300 clients to date and gather content on approximately 80 schools per year. The information that is in the excel files is also in our portal – it’s manually duplicated into the database. This has been the solution to date because we are not able to manipulate and analyze the content that is in the portal database. We are also not able to easily see what content needs to be gathered as it regards school data from one year to the next when we look at school data in our portal, as we are looking at school profile tabs, not a database that we can manipulate and see at a micro and macro scale. With the school data file, we must verify/update the data every year, throughout the year, as schools do not release all data at once. Further, schools don’t publish content in the same place on their websites annually. We have to scour sites to find data and, at times, call schools for the data. What we do is highlight all cells grey in May. Then, as we get the new season’s data, we remove the highlight from the cell. So it is very easy for us to know what data is last year vs this year. The solution must give us the ability to sort and filter as one does in Excel. It must allow us to highlight cells, which, upon being highlighted, will turn text in the portal profile tabs red so we can easily see, whether in the database or the portal school profile tabs, if content is new or old. We must be able to edit the content in the database interface or in the portal school profile pages. With the client data and results file, the content is currently in an excel file because we need the ability to look at our current clients and past clients all at once. We need to often look at our track record and manipulate data to understand what results we need - for example, how many more clients must get an interview or offer – to cross a certain success threshold.  We also conduct analyses to understand many things (how many clients attended a certain college, were over 32 years old, had a GPA between 2.5-3.0, were male, from West Point, attended HBS, etc). We must be able to edit the content in the database interface or in the portal client profile pages. We need the ability to filter/sort just as we do with excel files. We need to be able to track various metrics, such as how many people get interviews, offers, scholarships, average scholarship amount, number of females that get offers vs males who get offers, females that get scholarships vs males who get scholarships, etc.Skills: MariaDB, Database Design, PHP Script, Back-End Development, Laravel, PHP, Database, MySQL, RESTful API

description: Currently we have separate queues for each process server (e.g. "Queue Agent1-i-0d764779f5169f8e0"); this causes problems when we re-create the process servers.  This is because a user's job would explicitly tie itself to a process server, requiring the job to be updated when the newly-named process server is created. We need an "environment queue" to abstract over the specific process servers.
